awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Multiscale Additive Manufacturing Instrument with Integrated 3D Printing and Robotic Assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, the Nexus, a new instrument enabling robotic manufacturing for complex systems spanning dimensional scales between 1:1000 of an inch and 1 foot, will be developed. The proposed infrastructure will be located at University of Louisville's regional NSF National Nanotechnology Coordinated Infrastructure site in order to facilitate US researcher access to unique robotic assembly and additive manufacturing capabilities. The Nexus will contribute novel hardware and software for rapid prototyping of emerging microsystems, microrobots, wearable sensors, and multimaterial nanoscale systems. This project will pave the way for the physical realization of future advanced technology prototypes, such as hand-held microfactories for micro and nano technology, the next generation soft robots, and higher performance solar energy conversion systems. Engineering students using this MRI infrastructure will be exposed to an education environment that emphasizes precision robotics, microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) and advanced manufacturing skills. Imparting this knowledge to graduates is invaluable in keeping manufacturing jobs and startup companies in the U.S., since labor costs are not a factor when harnessing the potential of autonomous micromachines. 

The Nexus will be capable of multidimensional 100 nanometer positioning accuracy over meter distances for manufacturing of millimeter to computer tablet-sized integrated systems. Innovative custom process capabilities on the Nexus will include: 1) a fiber loom substation for smart fabrics, wearable sensors and soft robots, 2) 3D robotic microassembly alongside aerosol jetting thin film deposition capability for microrobots, in-situ packaged microsystems, and robot sensor skins, 3) a custom ultrasonic metal-polymer printing on robotic positioners for novel multimaterial plasmonic and bio-sensors, and 4) a photonic sintering station for nanostructured thin films.  The design of Nexus will be carried out with in-house simulation tools using evolutionary search methods from design databases, in order to 1) reduce project risks, 2) guarantee high-yield manufacturing, and 3) optimize the system cost. The design framework will guide the development of Nexus software for the automation of robotic transfer motions between substations, intelligent process control, and more intuitive human-machine interfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

inst.inst_name: University of Louisville Research Foundation Inc

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop the NeXus - a novel instrument combining microassembly, additive manufacturing techniques, and other packaging capabilities. The system hardware and software was completed in 2021 by the project 25 member project team at the University of Louisville (UofL), and it is now housed in a laboratory located at the Shumaker Research Building (SRB), staffed by personnel from UofL's Robotics Institute (LARRI), and the Micro-Nano-Technology Center (MNTC). 

A custom user interface screen allows operators to program automated manufacturing sequences, to obtain machine status information, or to manually intervene in advanced manufacturing processes. Operators can use the NeXus prototype demonstrator microsystem products that are normally very expensive and time-consuming to produce, including:  

1) Pressure sensitive robot skins on flexible electronic polymer substrates.  

2) Microrobots built by unique wire bonding and microassembly technology.

3) Soft actuator surfaces with embedded metal and piezoelectric wires. 

4) Perovskite Solar Cells for energy harvesting.

5) Functionalized Electronic Textiles, combining fibers, 3D-printed and inter-weaved electronic junctions. 

To manufacture demonstrators, the NeXus utilizes multiple robots, precision positioners, manipulation tools, and additive manufacturing process and packaging capabilities, including:

1) Aerosol InkJet system integrated with motorized positioning stages for depositing multi-material features 20-30 micron wide, and under micron thick. 

2) Custom Ultrasonic Printhead configured for metal interconnect formation for wire bonding, currently operating with diameters below 50 microns.

3) Custom Microassembly Station for microrobots including mm-size robotic arms and cm-size micro crawlers powered by light.

4) Custom Printed Circuit Board prototyping station, that allows precision pick and place of small electronic components onto flexible substrates.

5) Intense Pulsed Laser Sintering station used to cure thin and thick 3D- printed films.

6) Custom Additive 3D printing heads including a dual head fused filament integrated with robotic arms.

7) A Fiber Loom station, used to create electronic textiles for wearable devices.

8) Various end-effector process tools, including microgrippers, dispensers, and probers.

9) Various metrology and test tools including microscope visual inspection, electric probing and strength testing.

The Nexus will make advanced manufacturing with robotics more accessible, since a new generation of users will be trained and exposed to this exciting technology.  In addition, the design of the NEXUS tool brings together researchers from the fields of robotics, controls, microfabrication, 3D printing, and materials.  It requires them to work together and become more familiar with each others fields, which is positive for engineering and society. The NEXUS tool will be a showcase for advanced manufacturing and will help promote this critical technology which is so important to the future health of our nation.  Videos created about the NeXus system will be made available to the general public, thus increasing their awareness about robotics and advanced manufacturing that has the same cost to run anywhere on earth. This instrument also has potential applications in military garment devices, biomedical and antimicrobial textiles, and personal electronics. Flexible and breathable solar cells can complement conventional greener sources of energy.

A provisional patent was filed in Summer 2021, encompassing all technologies of the NeXus system. In Fall 2021, two commercialization projects (customer discovery) were conducted in support of startups to commercialize the NeXus intellectual property. These efforts will continue in the future. Prospective manufacturers who show interest in licensing materials-based university research typically have concerns about scaling up manufacturing. Since the NeXus can demonstrate the ability to attach micro components, circuits and terminations to flexible substrates and individual fibers using automation, and to print and package large sensor arrays, it will encourage technology transfer from the university to small businesses.

The NeXus system is part of the UofL Robotics Institute (LARRI), MNTC (MicroNanoTechnology Center) and the NSF National Nanotechnology Coordinated Intractructure network (NNCI), its unique capabilities will be widely advertised and marketed by all these entities. Standard Operating Procedures of the NeXus system will be made available on our website. We anticipate that the NeXus system will catalyze additional research and open up unique opportunities for the development and prototyping of novel products and systems. In the near future, as early as 2023, the NeXus will be made available to users within the NNCI Network, thus enabling any US-based researcher to access this instrument.


Last Modified: 12/21/2021
Modified by: Dan O Popa

Images (1 of )
  • This image shows the final implementation of NeXus located at University of Louisville Robotics Institute. In the future, this instrument will be made available nationwide through the National Nanotechnology Coordinated Infrastructure (NNIC) network.
    Danming Wei
    Copyrighted
    Dan O Popa
    NeXus Implementation
  • In these images, 40 micro Aluminum wire is bonded to Gold and Copper microrobot and circuit electronic pads using a custom ultrasonic bonder mounted on a NeXus robot.
    Danming Wei
    Copyrighted
    Dan O Popa
    Ultrasonic Bonding Tool
  • Using three of the NeXus robots, textile fibers are aligned with microgripper arrays to realize electronic and mechanical interconnections and functionalize the e-textile.
    Danming Wei
    Copyrighted
    Dan O Popa
    E-Textile Fabrication
  • The NeXus can integrate many tools to demonstrate the manufacturing process of a touch-sensitive robotic skin sensor array.
    Andriy Sherehiy
    Copyrighted
    Dan O Popa
    Fabrication Process Flow
  • This diagram shows a top view of the NeXus subsystems.
    Danming Wei
    Copyrighted
    Dan O Popa
    Top View NeXus Design
  • The NeXus uses an Aerosol Jetting Print head to deposit 30 micron feature lines using semiconductor, insulators or metal inks. In this picture, Silver ink lines are deposited during the manufacturing of pressure sensitive strain gauges on both sides of a flexible substrate.
    Alex Curry
    Copyrighted
    Dan O Popa
    Robotic Skin Sensor
